snippet.title: Burger bun-anza: New Coast burger joint sells out
snippet.content: IT'S almost eight months after opening his new cafe in Buderim and Shalom Persal is struggling to keep up with demand. A bold transition from coffee and cakes to burgers has paid dividends, with hungry customers flocking to the shop which is part of the popular Middy's complex on Main St. "It's taken off really fast, quicker than we thought," Spicy Butter owner Mr Persal said. He was busy preparing for the lunch rush when we caught up with him. He said the move had been made about two weeks ago and the business was still in the final stages of the transition, but it hadn't stopped punters piling in for a taste. "We just sort of wanted to change it a bit and bring something else a bit different to Buderim," Mr Persal said. Now open for lunch and dinner from Tuesday-Saturday, burger meals and ready-made meals are the mainstays of the menu. Coffees are still available until about 5pm and for those with a sweet tooth, rest easy in the knowledge that home-made cakes and muffins aren't lost. "We will get the cakes coming back soon," Mr Persal said. Mr Persal was urgently conducting interviews and trials with new staff, having run the business alone with the help of family and friends. His partner was assisting yesterday, but was juggling looking after their young kids at the same time. The demand for his burgers has been such that it not only requires extra hands, but extra stock too. "We ran out of everything on Friday," he said. A couple of bread rolls and a few tomatoes were all that was left, forcing Mr Persal to close on Saturday. "That won't happen again," he said with a laugh. After eight months he said things were "looking a bit better now". Opening from 11am-9pm, the menu was "simple" with four burgers and a lamb kebab on offer, as well as two kinds of fries and snacks for kids. Mr Persal said the lamb kebab had proven most popular so far, with plenty of people grabbing a kebab containing 14-hour, slow-cooked lamb, tzatziki, tabouli, lettuce, tomato and onion. "Everyone seems to be getting that," he said.
